...writing because I've just been so down and frustrated and disgusted and stressed and..well, you see why I've put off writing. I'm laying down on my bed, listening to Yahoo's Launchcast.  Specifically I've been stuck on the "Martini Lounge" station for over a week now and have listened to the "New Vocal Standards" and "Classic Vocal Standards" stations for at least a day each. The Martini Lounge has the feeling of a decent Jazz Club I guess.  They play new and classic sounds such as Louis Armstrong, Basia, Anita Baker and Billie Holiday.  They even play French music!  Okay okay...so I don't really like the French in general, but this music is COOL!  It's also pretty relaxing. The New Vocal Standards takes contemporary artists and combines them with the classic standards us old people enjoy so much.  I mean, imagine Frank Costello singing "My Funny Valentine" or Sinead O'Connor singing "Bewitched, Bothered & Bewildered!" Very cool.  Another relaxing station.  The Classic Vocal Standards is just that.  All those classic standards that you automatically know most of the words to and can't help but sing along with!  Frank Sinatra, The Andrew Sisters, Perry Como, and Sammy Davis, Jr.!  How could you possibly resist? I'm sorry.  I'm just rambling about the music because I needed something to talk about besides all the CRAP that's been weighing me down.  I need some down time, some away time from home, school AND work...just a day..a couple of hours..ANYTHING.  Just thinking about trying to schedule the time in hurts my head.  Until then I have to hang in there and just try and not think about all the CRAP going on...while surviving all the CRAP going on. CALGON TAKE ME AWAY!!!! Can someone please tell me why that never seems to work in real life?

Well, after a couple of hours of going over and over with different color schemes, I finally found one I like!  It sort of reminds me of an ice cream cone..either that or poodles.  Don't ask me why.  I really like the pink, browns and cream colors together.  

In the end it was the WebWhirlers (http://www.webwhirlers.com/colors/wizard.asp) "Colour Wizard" that helped me pull the scheme together.  I found one focus color I was interested in and popped it into the Wizard and it spit out the triad mix, complementary color, an analogous mix, a split complementary mix, a tint and shade mix, a chromatic variations mix and a saturation variation mix.  I went with the tint and shade mix for my focus color of pink.

So, I hope you like it.  If the pink is just TOO bright, let me know.  I was trying to balance the dark brown and the pink because the spaces I have them in require the text color to be the same.

And I *did* like the scheme I was using earlier...I just was experimenting with something and accidentially messed it up and therefore had to either fiddle with the old one AGAIN until I got it right, or create a whole new one from scrap.  I decided to start from scrap.

Let me know what you think!

Moment One - I have been dropped into the world of college freshmen.  Youngsters just out of high school and going through the movements of the "first day" of college.  They multiply like flies.  I was sitting on a bench, sweating in the hot sun across from the Language Arts building and there was just one.  She was sitting, phone glued to ear while chit chatting with her boyfriend as he lies in bed, half awake listening to her tittering.  Another one who knows the first one, (tittering into the phone), happens by and sits down.  And then another.  And then two more.  And then all of them get on phones, call others, and suddenly instead of one, there is a swarm. They stand, buzzing amongst each other, comparing notes on what classes each of them is taking, who is in class with whom, which teachers are just SO boring, and who is working where now.  They have designated this small bench, sitting in the sun across from the Language Arts building, the one I have been sitting on this whole time, their "spot" and vow to meet here each day. I wonder what they'll do when it rains. ************************ Moment Two - My American Lit teacher looks like a goth grown up.  Black slacks and dress shirt sporting Goth Black dyed hair pulled up into a short pony tail, sporting large round gold post earrings. With his pointy nose in a thin rat-like face he perches on the table in the front of the classroom, nervously swinging his legs back and forth, telling the mostly teenage class to expect to hear him spout stupidity, (his word), many times during the semester, all the while insisting that we argue the "idea" rather than the person. ~sigh~ Joyous.  I get to discuss "ideas" about early American Literature with a stupid person and a bunch of teenagers.  Can my day get any more idiotic? ************************ Moment Three - My Brit Lit teacher is a little better.  A throwback to the sixties with her rough woven skirt with "ethnic" designs crossstitched across her hip, long curly hair and Birkenstock sandals...with just a touch of "Valley Girl" thrown in for good measure.  She's enthusiastic about her subject and eager to get started.  Usually a good sign in a teacher. The class is more mixed than the American Lit, with a couple more "adults" than the earlier class, (only three people over 20 in a class of almost 40), and it's definitely more animated.  A couple of English Geeks sit across from me, comparing notes on the many novels they have read.  The girl in back is betrayed though by the romance novel falling out of her purse at her feet.  I can see that they will be entertaining in class. ;-) Looking again at the class, or rather...*listening* again to the class I wonder at the instructor's ability to guide the class through without losing control of the flow and ebb of the subject being discussed.  After her "interactive" lecture goes off course for the majority of the class time I raise my hand to make a comment and successfully pull the topic back on course.  The instructor points at me, smiles radiently at finally having brought the class to the point she was trying to make all along and finally moves the "interactive" lecture along. This is going to be a LONG semester.

I've waited so long to write this that you've probably forgotten. So. When we last left our story I had just received a letter from B, (the bio father), that indicated that he had not received my letter and so had NO idea that I was eight months pregnant with his child. I remember vividly sitting on the couch in the living room of the apartment with my boyfriend on one side and my roommate K on the other. I must have had a shocked look on my face because they both asked me what was wrong. I told them that it didn't look like he had received my letter. Now understand that this whole time every one of my friends believed that he was just copping out and wasn't answering to save his own booty. His letter, at least to me, proved otherwise. I had gotten to know him pretty well in the short time we were together. He talked a lot and I listened a lot. I think he was nervous. Moving on. After agonizing over what to do, I decided to write rather than call. I'm a horrible phone person and usually rely on the other person to provide fodder while all I do is answer questions or expand on what the other person is talking about. Irrevelent fact, but fact nonetheless. On the other hand, I excelled at the written word and was pretty darn good at letters. So I wrote another letter. I sent the letter to his work address and tried to make it look as official as possible. You never know who opens the upper echelon's mail, so I tried to make it look personal, but offical in some manner. Yah, right. In the letter I tried once again to just keep to the facts. Regardless of the fact that the emotions ran just under the surface, (I was pregnant folks!), the letter was pretty...emotionless. I once again got straight to the facts after only a line or two opening chit chat and told him I was pregnant. I also went over the no rocking the boat, full responsibility, etc. stuff. I let him know he could have as much or as little contact as he wished. It was up to him. I told him when I was due and that when he got there I should have already had the baby. [I can't remember where, but I remember seeing an old journal of mine with some of this stuff in it. I took a bit to look around but I can't seem to find what I was looking for. If I do at a later date I'll post it.] I sent the letter off with a feeling of trepidation. I didn't call him for a reason and I knew that he wouldn't wait. He'd call. I wasn't sure that I would be up to it. Every day after that was spent with the knowledge of that impending call firmly in the back of my head. I hoped that someone would be home when I received it. Either my boyfriend or my roommate. Anyone. Of course, just like any good story, I didn't get my wish. My roommate had just taken my boyfriend with her to the pet store to get a new goldfish when the phone rang. I knew it was him. No, I didn't have caller ID...it was instinct. I was right. I wish I could tell you what was said. I remember him sounding pretty down, anxious. Nothing truly unexpected really. He wasn't accusatory really. He didn't do the "how could this have happened?" crap that a lot of guys might have done. (Advantage of him being nine years older.) He sounded more guilty than anything else. The conversation pretty much went over what I had said in the letter. I didn't want to make waves. I understood his familial obligations and didn't intend on ratting him out to his wife. I intended on keeping the child and raising the baby myself. I didn't intend on asking him for anything and he'd never have to worry about me and the baby. Yes. He could see the baby if he wanted to, I'd even make sure he knew when the baby was born if he'd give me a phone number that was good. I didn't extend it. Hell. I never wanted the phone call to happen! A nice note would have been fine enough for me. *rolling eyes* I left off telling him I'd notify him when I gave birth and would see him when he came into town. Truthfully I was shaking during the entire phone call and cried for a while after I got off. It wasn't fifteen minutes later though that my roommate and boyfriend came home and I had to relive the whole experience. It wasn't a week later that my boyfriend couldn't handle the baby thing any longer and dumped me. Of course, by this time we had moved into the house my roommate had bought with one of the bouncers and renovations had begun. My boyfriend still had a key to the house though as he was practically my roommate's best friend by now and was helping with renovations.   So not only did I get dumped, but I got my face rubbed in it DAILY. See, I would come home from work and HE would be there working on the house. Or he'd be having dinner there. Or he'd be hanging out with K. Torture. It was at that point in time that I started hanging out with DD.  A girlfriend of mine had insisted we go out to get me out of my post-boyfriend blues.  Post-boyfriend?  How the fuck is it POST if he's THERE all the time?  Nevermind.  I digress.  As I was saying, my girlfriend wanted me to go out with her and I finally relented.  Oh the looks I would get!  That first night I ran into an old friend of mine from work (DD) and we started making it a weekly get together.  We'd meet up at the same club, hang out and make fun of people dancing.  I walked around with what must have looked like some exotic rum drink but what actually was a mixed fruit drink.  It was nice having my own pet bartender.  She would make me fruit drinks all night and it wouldn't cost me a dime.  But the looks and comments I would get were hilarous!  If only they had known! HAH! Okay, that wasn't really part of the "backstory" but it's a fun tidbit that I enjoy remembering.  At that point in time I had started having braxton hicks contractions on a regular basis, so I would go out and the braxton hicks would kick in about 10pm-ish.  It was no big deal, but it was fun watching the look of horror when DD would ask me how I was feeling and I replied, "Crappy.  I keep having these damn contractions!"   Of course, there WAS the one time the braxton hicks were so bad that I had to have DD drive me over to Skinifatz to tell K that I couldn't drive her car home as my contractions were so bad.  If you knew DD you'd know that having him enter Skinifatz was a sign of the purest of loves. As a DJ of the highest degree country was BELOW him you see. Regardless.  Once again I got seriously off-track.  Sorry.  Where was I?  Okay.  So finally my time came.  The day I started having contractions I went car shopping.  I had made an appointment to see a car and by the time the appointment came along I was well into regular contractions but far from real labor.  When the salesman asked me how I was doing I said, "I'm in labor.  How are you today?"  *snicker*  Typical man he panicked.  I looked over the car but didn't test drive it.  We went into the finance department to fill out the loan paperwork and the salesman panicked again and told the woman that we needed to hurry as I was in labor.  She calmly asked me how far apart my contractions were, I told her and she looked at him and told him that we had plenty of time.  We serenely smiled at each other with the womanly knowledge that no man understands. I finished my paperwork and went home.  I couldn't tell you what I did the rest of that day, but at about midnight I was still having regular contractions and called the hospital to see if I should come in.  My water hadn't broken yet but I had been leaking amniotic fluids for about a week and my doctor had told me that if I started having regular contractions to go in as by leaking amniotic fluids I could have given the baby an infection.  K (roommate) and D (bouncer roommate) were my birthing partners, so I went up to the second floor to wake them up.  Standing in K's doorway I gently knocked on the door and quietly called, "K.  K.  It's time to go."  D was immediately in the doorway of his room asking if it was time to go to the hospital and R, (K's Marine bfriend), was up and half-dressed before I finished talking to D.  Go figure. Panic ensued and K, D and R all got themselves together, my stuff in the car and the car out front ready for me to go before we took off.  Of course before we even hit the car D was so nervous he threw up two times and K was so hyper it was like she had just consumed ten cups of coffee all at once!  While we took D's car (bigger) K drove because D was too nervous to drive.  They both sat in the front while I slid around in the huge backseat of D's Lincoln.  R followed along in his car.  The drive was interesting.  I had opted to have my baby at Bethesda Naval Hospital rather than the closer Army Hospital because of all the scuttlebutt I had heard about the Army Hospital.  I had also been to Bethesda once before about a year before; but that's a whole other story.  Bethesda is about an hour drive from Quantico and all the way there everytime I had a contraction K sped up to over 80 mph.  Her foot seemed steadily press downward the louder I got.  As each contraction waned though, her foot would lighten and the miles per hour lessened considerably.  She needn't have hurried though.  When we finally got there and I went in for my inital exam I was told that I was only two centimeters dilated and that, to admit me, I had to be four to five centimeters dilated.  The arrogant doctor didn't listen to what I told him about leaking amniotic fluid, he didn't listen to me at all.  He merely had me lay down, stuck his fingers up my crotch, and then told me that I wasn't far enough along to be admitted.  I asked him what he thought I should do.  He told me I could either walk the halls to hopefully induce labor, or go home and wait it out. It was almost 1am by now.  I went out to tell the troops what the doctor said and decide what we wanted to do.  To stay or not to stay?  In the end they asked me and I told them that I was sure it was time and I wanted to stay and try and have the baby.  I told them all they could go home if they wanted to, but all three of them opted to stay and walk the halls of Bethesda with me. Once again it's late and I have to get up in only three and a half hours.  Hopefully the brat starts school today (another story).  I HAVE to finish the story today because there are other things to talk about. Fate OUT.

I just finished reading Lamb by Christopher Moore and have decided I need to pick up some of his other books. Talk about funny! If you didn't know it, Lamb is supposed to be another gospel. This one is about Jesus' childhood as written by his friend Levi called Biff. Yep. Don't take this one to church folks! I will say though that it is FUNNY and would recommend it to anyone who isn't a complete religious conservative or doesn't know anything about the bible. Pick it up! I also just got done reading Best New American Voices: The Best New Fiction From America's Top Writing Programs. This is the 2004 edition guest edited by John Casey. I also read the 2003 edition, which was guest edited by Joyce Carol Oates. I preferred Oates selections personally, but all the stories were help in understanding the short story. I think I'm getting a better feel. That's a good thing because I keep thinking of those stories I want to write [procrastinator] and they get kicked around in my head until their bruised..but maybe that's a good thing. I guess I won't know until I write them, right? Nevertheless...the backstory comes first. I have the next couple of days off, so maybe I can get some time to write then. *crossing fingers* Oh..and one great thing happened today. Went to lunch with my boss and one of her friends and when I came back one of my friends had stopped by and left a card and a little bamboo shoot in a class vase that has that little squishy gel stuff they sometimes put plants in??? You know, it comes in different colors? Well this is the clear kind and the vase looks like two shot glasses stuck together in a kinda > < shape but softer. Hanging from a circle of beads that are around the waist of the vase hangs a small aluminum tag that says, "bloom." Just a little thing but really nice. On the outside of the card it says, "Cherie Leonard" with "(AKA: Queen of Everything)" underneath and the card has a toddler in feetsie pajamas with his forehead flat two stairs up and his hands behind him. Inside it reads, "If it isn't one thing, it's another. Hang in there." My friend wrote, "Cherie, Don't forget that you are a ROCK! By far of the strongest people I have ever met. Luv ya Lots! - L" I just made my day. Really it did. I've just been having such a hard time lately and I've hovered on the edge of depression for a couple of months now. I just happened to mention to her on IM the other night about my car and when I came back from lunch today these things were here. IT'S THE SMALLEST THINGS IN LIFE THAT SOMEHOW MATTER THE MOST IN THE WORST OF TIMES. I don't know if anyone else ever said that..but it's a truth that I know and understand. Thank you L.

I think that during a person's life there will always be times when you want to kill one or another of your parents. Well, not ~really~ kill them, just plot their demise in your head. You devise some horrible way for them to die where you might or might not have a hand in what happens; but in the end they are truly dead....in the story of your mind anyway. Tonight was one of my nights. After an evening of moving into my apartment, my mother picks me up. I casually ask her,"so, how did the moving go?" Then she proceeds to tell me how they moved her couch into my apartment, (which I knew about), and how they knocked multiple holes into my front closet door, (and I *finally* get to live in a place that DOESN'T have doors with holes in them and they fucking knock holes in them. Oh gee thanks.), and finally how they took MY couch and took it to so and so's house, (which I did NOT know about). Okay. So it's not like I had a life and death attachment to this couch. It's not like this was my first purchase with my own money. It was a hand-me-down for god's sake! That's not the point. The point is that she talks to me months ago about the *possiblity* of buying me a new couch when she moves out, we talk about the *possibility* of BOTH couches fitting. (I tell her yes multiple times) And she never thinks to talk to me about it. She'll be sleeping on the couch during the week. I have a desk for my computer, but no place to do my homework. It was hard enough with just me and my brat and one couch but now we have to share one very small couch with THREE people??? I don't think so. So now I'm upset. She offers, (like a good mommie would), to have them bring it back. Right. And be the bad guy and listen to them bitch and moan and give me a hard time? I don't think so. But then she offers to just buy me a new couch now. Uh huh. And we're gonna do that while my car is still without an engine? Riiiight. Well, we'll just buy a loveseat. Riiiight while I owe money to her asshole of a hubby.Who likes to pick and pick and complain and just mention offhand exactly HOW MUCH money I owe him on every occasion he possibly can and sometimes he shouldn't. Oh, and let's not forget every conversation he has with his oldest daughter, (who has as low of an opinion about me as he does), about my every fault. No. I think I'll sit on the fucking floor thankyouverymuch. You know, I love my mother very much. But tonight I plotted her death in my mind. Note: This entry was written Tuesday, 09 Mar 04/2300ish.

Many times when I start this missive to you, I describe where I am,what I am doing...something to give you an idea of what is going on with me. This time won't be much different. Tonight I sit at my laptop, struggling with a space key that barely works. I only got home half hour ago from celebrating with my friend L. She just got a new job. We went out to our favorite place to get our favorite beer with her new(er) roommate. We haven't done anything like that in eons. Of course, she invited another friend of hers...a completely hot guy...who she forgot to introduce to me!! ARGH! Well, next time. No big. I'm tired as hell and I really need to get to sleep. And this clearly broken space key is driving me nuts. Really the reason I'm writing..typing...whatever...is because I'm reading this great book about writing. It recommends, just like all the other twenty million books out there on writing, that to write..really write you should write every day.I mean, EVERY day. So here I am. Writing. Not really what I should be writing about, but writing nonetheless. I really have an idea in my head for a short story. It's been there for a while, but I'm completely intimidated by the THOUGHT of writing a short story rather than a poem that I have been stalling. So I'm going to start writing every day. Remember the Moon Survives For Pamela by Barbara Kingsolver Remember the moon survives, draws herself out cresent-thin, a curved woman. Untouchable, she bends around the shadow that pushes itself against her, and she waits. Remember how you waited when the nights bled their darkness out like ink, to blacken the days beyond, to blind the morning's one eye. This is how you learned how to draw your life out like the moon, curled like a fetus around the shadow. Curled in your bed, the little hopeful flowers of your knees pressed against the wall and its mockery of paint, always the little-girl colors on the stones of the ordinary prison: the house where you are someone's daughter, sister, someone's flesh, someone's blood. The Lamb and Mary have left you to float in this darkneess like a soup bone. You watch the cannibal feast from a hidden place and pray to be rid of your offering. The sun is all you wait for, the light, guardian saint of all the children who lie like death on the wake on the household crime. You stop your heart like a clock: these hours are not your own. You hide your life away, the lucky coin tucked quickly in the shoe from the burglar, when he comes. Because he will, as sure as shoes. This is the one with all the keys to where you live, the one you can't escape, and while your heart is stopped, he takes things. It will take years to learn: why you hold back sleep from the mouth that opens in the dark, why you will not feed it with the dreams you sealed up tight in a cave of tears; why the black widow still visits you, squeezes her venom out in droplets, stringing them like garnets down your abdomen, the terrifying jewelry of a woman you wore inside, a child robbed in the dark. Finally you know this. You have sliced your numbness open with the blades of your own eyes. From your years of watching you have grown the pupils of a cat, to see in the dark. And these eyes are your blessing. They will always know the poison from the jewels that are both embedded in your flesh. They will always know the darkness that is one of your names by now, but not the one who knows, behind the rising, falling tide of shadow, the moon is always whole. You take in silver through your eyes, and hammer it as taut as poems in steel into the fine bright crescent of your life: the sickle, the fetus, the surviving moon.

These words are mine and they are true. - Chief Meninock My words are as true as I can know them to be. That's the best anyone can do I think. To try and show truth of themselves to the world as much as possible. Oh, we each have those moments of white lies. It doesn't matter who you tell them to or why. We all have those moments in life where the truth would just not benefit the person who wants to hear it, nor would it benefit yourself to tell them that truth. It won't hurt them either. I mean, it's not your best friend asking you about that ridiculous dress that she thinks makes her look so hot, (but really makes her look like a whore looking for a john); or the boyfriend who you know you just have to drop because you just can't stand him anymore and he's just about }{ close to asking you to marry him. I'm talking the Life truths. Showing the closest thing to truth of yourself to those that you interact with on every level. No hiding. It's a hard thing to do. I should know. I've hidden myself to some level my entire Life I think. That hiding from the world physically and from the infinite amount of interaction with people that must happen if you are to be a part of it. People are complicated. People give you headaches. People give you heartaches. They make you think about what you're doing and saying and thinking and feeling and a myriad of other things you sometimes don't want to do. People make you angry. People make you frustrated. People make you want to pound something until it's bloody. They make you sad. They make you scared. They make you cry. They make you smile. They make you happy. They make you love. They make you feel the amazing wonder of what it is to be alive. Honesty characterizes the person and enables him to create an identity, to communicate a real presence, and to establish authentic bonds with others. The individual increasingly comes to know who he is through the stand he takes when he expresses his ideas, values, beliefs, and convictions, and through the declaration and ownership of his feelings. - Clark Moustakas With every word you speak, with every thought you think, you are creating yourself. You are made up of not only the bone, blood, muscle and gristle but the ideas, beliefs, values and convictions that you express through your words and actions. What is all of that if you are not sharing it with others? Why do you exist if not to be a part of that world just outside your window? I always remember looking at that world out there (still do to some extent) and wondering why I'm not a part of it. Oh, I go to work and have to talk to people there. I interact many levels separated with people on the web. I see my family from time to time. I live with my daughter. I am not completely separate from the world. I am not a part of it either. I interact peripherally. That surface part where you exchange niceties with people you come in contact with during your day. Very few people know me more than that. Shoot. My best friends don't know me all that well. They know me more than most though. "Come to the edge He said. They said: We are afraid. Come to the edge He said. They came. He pushed them, and they flew..." -Guillaume Apollinaire I should have written weeks ago. I should have written just after it happened, when all of those thoughts were fresh in my mind. I know I had some people worried. For that I apologize. It was not my intention. I was better than anyone thought though. I somehow let go of much of what I was holding onto in one single day. Without me knowing it even. I mean, one second I was holding on for dear life...and the next, it was gone. Not in a sad way either. More of a relief. A big, deep breath that I had been holding for weeks..months even. Tension built up in-between my shoulders...as if wings were starting to form...and then..release. That first weekend after was full of happiness. I couldn't have defined it other than that word I think. It was just a lightness about myself and my time that weekend. Was it really two weekends ago? It seems as if it was a lifetime ago. It is one of the blessings of old friends that you can afford to be stupid with them. - Ralph Waldo Emerson I just have to give due to my friends here. I dealt with this crisis of mind differently than I ever remember doing so before. I didn't sit in my room, at my desk, or even in my car and stew over all of these things that were happening. I didn't necessarily try and solve every nuance by myself. Surely I thought of solutions. Surely I thought to myself, "oh dear gods what do I do now?" But. I also made a phone call. One, simple, relatively short phone call. A friend is one to whom you can pour out the contents of your heart, chaff and grain alike. Knowing that the gentlest of hands will take and sift it, keep what is worth keeping and with a breath of kindness, blow the rest away. - Unknown I cut class and poured our my mind, my heart and my frustrations with it all. I stood in the bookstore, fingers brushing across magazines, cookbooks, thrillers and self-help books while I talked to one of The Best Friends. I do think this is the first time I've done this with that particular friend. I said a quick, "hello, how ya' doin," and moved rapidly to the "So. Do you have a minute to listen to me?" Let me tell you, reader, that it might have been one of the most pertinent breakthroughs in my life as a human being. (No. You can't ask me what I was before that.) No distance of place or lapse of time can lessen the friendship of those who are thoroughly persuaded of each other's worth. - Robert Southey (1774 - 1843) You know what? He said, "yes," and proceeded to listen to me pour out my woes to my heart's content. And boy did I! This was before I sent that first email. I was confused, angry, sad and feeling completely without worth. I was trying to find the courage to have that sense of self-worth so I could do what I thought I deserved to do. So I could get answers I thought I deserved. Whether or not the other person thought so was irrevelent at the time. We need people in our lives with whom we can be as open as possible. To have real conversation with people may seem like such a simple, obvious suggestion, but it involves courage and risk. - Thomas Moore, PhD, in the essay "Embracing the Everyday" My friend listened. He gave me honest answers...some of them were even "I don't know." Which, I'm not sure if people know this, is OKAY. As a matter of a fact, I think it's better to say "I don't know" than to give a thousand words of advice. Sometimes just bouncing words off another person's brain is enough to click everything into place. I got off the phone 30 minutes later with an understanding of what I wanted to do...and the knowledge in myself that I could do this simple thing. And it was a simple thing..but oh so complicated. Friendship improves happiness, and abates misery, by doubling our joys, and dividing our grief. - Joseph Addison (1672 - 1719) I don't want to get into what happened afterwards. I did outline some of it here. I choose not to go into anything else surrounding those events other than to say that it did not end badly. Friendship is a sheltering tree. - Samuel Taylor Coleridge In the rush of daily living it's easy to forget all the remarkable people, real or fictional, who have been a part of your life. But if you just imagine they are near for a moment, you will realize that anyone who ever touched your heart is always with you, patiently waiting to emanate warmth and support whenever you remember to think of them. - Barbara Sher

My stomach is tight and churning this morning. You see, HE found my journal. I don't know if he found it before this, but last night, after I received his email and responded and then wrote here in my LJ...angrily and snippily because I was hurt and wanting so much not to be hurt or to show that I was hurt...he read it. Why do I do this? Why do I post here on LJ? Why not just write in a paper notebook and keep it all to myself? Why not write in Word on my computer and keep it under lock and key? Why not keep it "Friends Only" so only exactly those who I would like to read it would? Because this is my cry out into the world. These rantings and ramblings. These forays into my life, my heart, my mind, my world splayed out in front of you. It's by no means encompassing of my whole world. So much goes on that I do not touch upon here. Part of it is because, during the things I do during the day, I forget much. Or it's not significant. Or it's not something I want to share. Or it's not something I care to think about again, so why write it down for posterity? I write to share of myself. To connect, on some level, with the great big void out there. To touch someone, some how, some way, some time on some level....even if they never tell me. I do it because I am lonely to some extent. I don't have a best friend I can go to here and cry my woes out to, or beat about the shoulders with my frustrations. I don't have a significant other to cuddle with and whisper sweet nothings into their ear, or rant at until they cringe because my day didn't go just so. You can only tell a child so much about your adult world. I have few that I would talk to on the level I share here. Not to mention I don't sound quite so profound in person. I wonder about these things because, albeit last night was a shock to find out that he had read my entry here, I have, over recent days found out of other people who know of me from other places who read this. These are just those to who have told me. I must wonder then, who else is anonymously reading my entries and what might they make of them. I must also think about what I am putting out here for the public to read, versus those things that only my Friends list reads. So. Going back to the reasoning of why I do this mostly public. With the thought of people who know of me in some other capacity reading this, and the effect one single entry had on a person I care deeply about, I am going to have to seriously rethink what I post publicly. First and foremost this LJ is for me. A place for me to get out in writing what I cannot get out verbally. A place to vent, rant, rave, gush and bubble. If I feel then that I can share it with others, then it will be public. I don't want to stop writing for a crowd. I might write FOR myself, but I THINK of others when I write. How stupid would THAT be, writing for just myself all the time? Well, sometimes it makes for interesting reading. See THIS LJ entry. Well, I had to write this because of what has been on my mind. I went to bed last night thinking of HIM, and woke up thinking of HIM. TO HIM: If you're reading this to wonder what is going on in my mind...I never, ever meant to hurt you. Why would I hurt someone who I care for so so much? I am just in a froth thinking that we would let it end this way. Please call or write to me if you read this.

There was an article about spicing up how you express yourself in Personal Journaling and it had a small side bar that I wanted to share:
Dig Deeper
If the goal of your writing is to develop insights beyond laundry lists of activites, then using description artfully is one way to write more effectively. Try these ideas to add dimension to your writing through description.
  • Read cookbooks, restaurant revies and cooking magazines to expand your attitudes about description. Can you really describe salmon as "bold" or "ruthless"? Writers in this genre tend to reach into metaphors and unusual comparasions to describe simple food. Are there phrases that inspire your own descriptions?
  • Go online to read art reviews, or check out an art history book from your local library. how are paintings, drawings and sculptures described? This kind of writing is not literal, but very passionate, with comparasions and insights into the meaning of each brushstroke and curve. Would anyone dare describe Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel ceiling without passion? Walk through a textile or fabric store or outlet and notice all the variations of texture, color, pattern and depth. How would you describe this in writing?
  • Write about one of the happiest days of your life. Close your eyes to try and remember very specific details. Can you create new metaphors or comparasions to make you feel as if you're reliving that day? You will have achieved description nirvana if writing about it with passion suddenly makes you as content as you were that day. Think of this exercise as a cheap mood elevator, a simple mind vacation, and do it as often as you can.
Here's another piece from Personal Journaling from an article about journaling through your divorce.
Managing Anger
Ventilate & Incinerate The next time you've had it up to here with frustration and anxiety, give yourself free rein to write down all of your rage. Once you've expressed every nasty sentiment, rip those pages out of your journal and burn them. "It helps you symbolically let go," says Linda C. Senn, co-author of The Divorce Recovery Journal. "When I do this exercise, I kick the type up to 72-point bold on my computer for emphasis." If you prefer to write by hand, try using a black marker or a brightly colored pen to lend the same shouting quality to your intense feelings. Timed Tantrum Another good exercise is to set the kitchen timer for five or 10 minutes. This is your no-holds barred writing period to work out every mean and angry thought that has been running through your head. When time is up, shut your journal and make a concerted effort to leave the negativity behind on the page. One benefit of this technique is that you'll be able to look back at your feelings in a few weeks. You may be surprised at what a little time and perspective can do for your state of mind. Isn't it amazing? And it doesn't matter if it's classical, rap, pop, rock or new age...if you let it, it can effect you deeply. I had the worse day today. Oh, it didn't START out that way. I was fine coming into work. Sat down, got settled and started my work. Mood was fine. Far as I can remember anyway. About noonish my boss rolls in from the President's council. She opens her door, sets her stuff down..walks back to her door and tells me to get a pad of paper and come into her office. I grab a pen and paper and set my booty down in the chair across from her desk. AS SOON AS SHE OPENED HER MOUTH...I could practically SEE the little stress monsters literally JUMPING off of her shoulders, across the desk and grabbing hold of my shirt. When she feels confused or she doesn't know what she's talking about..she freaks. So the President asked her about things in our area that she didn't know anything about...so she freaked. Problem is...the solution MUST come from HER..not ME. So she sat there and practically threw those stress monsters all over me. By the time she was done I literally felt the weight of all of them across my shoulders and through my neck and back..sliming and crawling across my skin, hanging from the edges of me and bringing me down. I haven't felt that bad in months. Not since before May I believe. NOTHING I tried worked to lessen the stress. I did all the items on my TO DO list, I took a walk, I sat down to go read my magazine (reading Poets & Writers), talked to some people...anything to get my mind back where it belonged and the stress monsters off of my back. Nothing worked. I finally got off of work and on the way home...I cried. No reason other than this horrid horrid mood that had set itself upon me....weighing my whole body and mind down. Didn't go away when I picked up the brat. Didn't go away when I got home. Took a nap...went away a little bit. Got a phone call from my best friend Don...THAT helped a lot. We IMed last night for a long while. Another eye opening conversation like many I've had over the past month or so. I suppose eventually my friends will truly get me in line. Just before I left work someone popped online to IM me with an emergency. Her friend is pregnant and she asked her to consider adoption. Who does she call on? Well, of course I'm the logical choice. So I'm supposed to be talking to her tomorrow about 1pm my time. I have mixed feelings about the whole thing. I've counseled expectant girls who are thinking about adoption before. As far as I know, Lifetime (the adoption facilitator I used) still has my contact info if they want me to talk to a girl. I have mixed feelings because...well...isn't it obvious? Just read my posts over the last week or so. It's not hard to comprehend. But I'll do it anyway..I'll lay it all out for her..logical like..giving her the choices and the pros and the cons...and showing her the emotions that go along with all of that. How could I NOT show her the emotions? Many times, that's all you're left with after the adoption is over. The emotions are what drive the whole process. The joy of the adoptive parents. The sadness of the birthparent. The love of an adoptive parent as they bring their newly adopted child into their lives. The love of a birthparent as they hand their child over to practical strangers to care for the rest of the child's life. The happiness the child brings into the life of the adoptive family. The emotional hole left in the birth family. Talked to Navy tonight. Cleared up a lot of stuff I think.
